Sun of Faith - English: Now, Wicked Mara possessed two victory banners, one standing for desire, one standing fore doubt.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): བྱང་ཆུབ་ཀྱི་ཤིང་གི་དྲུང་དུ་རྩ་བཏང་བའི་སྟེང་དུ་བཞུགས་པ་མཉམ་བཞག་མཛད་པ་ལ། བདུད་ཀྱི་སྤྲུལ་པའི་ཕོ་ཉ་བདུན་འོང་བ་དང་། ཡང་དེ་དང་ཉེ་བར། བདུད་འདུལ་གྱི་བཀོད་པ་སྤྱི་དང་འདྲ་བ་འབྲི་བ་ལས། རིན་པོ་ཆེའི་བཞུགས་ཁྲི་མི་དགོས། ཡང་བྱང་ཆུབ་ཤིང་གཅིག་གི་རྩ་བ་ན། བཞུགས་ཚུལ་མཉམ་བཞག་མཛད་པ་ལ། ཤིང་གི་ཡལ་ག་ཆེ་ལ་དཀར་བ་ལོ་མ་རྣམས་ལྷ་མང་པོས་འཛིན་པ་འབྲི། །  །མངོན་བྱུང་དང་།  འདུལ་བའི་ལུགས་ལ།  སླུ་བྲིད་སྟོན་པའི་བདུད་ཀྱི་བུ་མོ་གསུམ་ཁོ་ན་འབྲི་སྟེ།  བདུད་བཏུལ་པའི་སྐོར་རོ། །
Manual - English: While sitting in equanimity under the Bodhi Tree (byang chub kyi shing), he is visited upon by seven messengers who are apparitions created by the demon. The scene of the Buddha taming the demon should be drawn as in the mainstream, hence there is no need to draw a throne.  In another scene, the Buddha sits in equanimity under a Bodhi Tree. The tree has big white branches with leaves held up by gods. According to the traditions of history (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya (‘dul ba), the only scene to be drawn here is three daughters of the demon trying to seduce the Buddha.

Sun of Faith - English: Then the banner of doubt fluttered. Mara investigated, and saw that the Bodhisattva had sat upon the Indestructable Throne. In order to obstruct the Bodhisattva, he appeared as a messanger with long matted hair and a coarse robe around his waist. In an urgent voice he said, "Devadatta has conquered Kapilavastu! You palace is destroyed! The Shakyas have been slain! Why do you remain on that seat?"
But the Bodhisattva knew that Mara would disrupt him by stirring up the three non-virtuous attitudes of desire for sense pleasures, harmful intent, and malice.
Then Mara appeared as himself and said, "How will you you attain unsurpassed wisdom?"

"Wicked One, because you undertook a single offering, you became the ruler of the Desire Realm," said the Bodhisattva. "Over three incalculable eons I performed billions upon billions of offerings. I have given away everything, from gold and jewels to my own hands and head, for the benefit of sentient beings. So there is no doubt that I will attain unsurpassed wisdom."
"You have just borne witness that I have performed this offering," said Mara. "Who will be witness to your offerings?“
Then the Bodhisattva touched the ground with his right hand, the hand created through many hundreds of meritorious deeds, and the said, "The Earth is my witness."
At that moment the Earth goddess, Prithvidevi emerged the Earth and with her palms joined, said, “It is just as the Blessed One has said.”
Thoroughly cowed by this, Wicked Mara went away.
Mara then summoned his daughters, Trisna, Rati,  and Raga—or Thirst, Pleasure, and Enjoyment—and dispatchced them.
Manual - English: As in the Abhiniskramana and the Vinaya draw only three daughters of Mara displaying tempation. This is the section on the Taming of Mara.

Sun of Faith - English: These three were the best of celestial daughters. But when they began to display their magic, the Bodhisattva magically transformed them into old women. They subsequently came to have devotion toward the Buddha and were liberated.
Inscription - English: Three yong women turned into old women

Sun of Faith - English: Next, Wicked Mara summoned all the demonic spirits, and this great army of demons of various bodies and faces, wielding an assortment of weapons, powerful, violent, and wild, 360 million in all, marched before him. Mara himself went forth with his bow drawn to his ear and they surrounded the Bodhisattva.
Inscription - English: While dwelling in Vajrāsana, (the Bodhisattva) tamed 360 million demons with compassion

Sun of Faith - English: Then the Bodhisattva settled in meditative absorption on kindness. Because of this, the weapons hurled by the demonic demons transformed into lotus, blue lotus, and other such flowers. The mountains hurled at him transformed in mansions made of flowers.

The gods of the pure realm deflected the violent winds and rain of stones. The rain of fuming filth transformed into sweet smelling things. All the attempts of the demons to harm him were thwarted and the demonic army scattered.

Since noise is the enemy of concentration, Mara turned the tree of enlightenment into crystal and shook it with wind, which produced a great tumult. Then the gods of the pure realm took hold of each leaf and quelled the din.

But still some demons remained there, so the gods of the pure realm banished them to the far side of the earth. They made a fearsome racket that could be heard from a great distance. The gods worried the Bodhisattva's absorption would be harmed, so they surrounded him with a forest of Katam trees twelve leagues thick. Then all the demons faded away.
